msDesc.head: Two medical tracts on the diseases of women

summary.seg:
The two main texts in this manuscript have a shared theme and may have had a common readership in fifteenth- and sixteenth-century England, but are preserved here in two parts that were produced separately from one another before being bound together at some later date. The two texts are gynaecological treatises, each with connections to the 'Trotula' group of texts that emerged from southern Italy, most probably Salerno, during the twelfth century, these being:
Liber de sinthomatibus mulierum ('The Book on the conditions of comen')
De curis mulierum ('Treatments for women')
De ornatu mulierum ('Women's cosmetics') The first text in MS Ii.6.33, The Boke of Rota, is a translation into Middle English of chapters from the Liber de sinthomatibus mulierum and De curis mulierum. The second, known as The Knowing of Woman's Kind in Childing, is based on selections from a French translation of Liber de sinthomatibus mulierum, the Non omnes quidem (mostly derived from Muscio's Gynaecia), the Gynaecia of pseudo-Cleopatra, and other sources, with (in Monica Green's words) 'considerable theoretical embellishments by the translator-adaptor' (Green (1997), p. 85). Both The Boke of Rota and The Knowing of Woman's Kind in Childing cleave to the tenets of Hippocratic gynaecology, such as the recognition of the benefits of sexual activity and menstruation, or the theory of the 'wandering womb'.

The material history of the manuscript has been obscured somewhat by the rebinding and repair of the volume. It is clear that the manuscript comprises two discrete parts: both are written on paper but of different stocks. The copying of the first dates to the sixteenth century and the second to the fifteenth century. The first part comprises two quires, originally of 18 leaves each. The first leaf of Quire 1 was perhaps a former pastedown, which has been excised when the manuscript was rebound. A stub before the beginning of Quire 2, and the absence of any interruption to the text, suggests that the 1st leaf was cancelled. The second leaf, now f. 18, has no conjoint leaf. The 17th and 18th leaves of Quire 2, to which the 1st and 2nd leaves would have originally been attached, are no longer present. It is possible, however, that these are in fact ff. 2:37-38, which appear to be from the same paper stock and bear notes by the same hand that was responsible for copying the text in the first part of the manuscript. This hand is nowhere to be found in the second part of the manuscript, which points to the two parts (their shared subject-matter notwithstanding) having been produced entirely separately and only bound together at a later juncture, rather than the second part being already in someone's possession and the first part being copied with the deliberate intention that the two be bound together. The damage that these leaves (ff. 2:37-38) have suffered, however, is of the same pattern as those towards the end of the second part of the manuscript, suggesting that they have been bound in this location for a lengthy period of time. The status of f. 39 is less clear, however. It too is of the same paper stock, so originally belonged with the leaves of the first part of the manuscript, but is more likely a remnant of an endleaf, pastedown or wrapper than part of either Quires 1 or 2.

The manuscript was placed into its current binding in 1974. It appears that it was at this point that it was separated from MS Ii.6.34, with which it had been bound in 'paper boards' (according to an unpublished description by M.R. James) since at least the publication of a catalogue of the University Library's manuscripts in 1858, when the two were described as being in a single volume. However, earlier records of these two manuscripts show that this was not always the case. The two are recorded separately - and must therefore have been physically discrete items - in the list of the contents of the library of John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely, published in 1697 by Edward Bernard. Moore's manuscripts (and printed books) came to Cambridge University Library in the year after his death, at the gift of George I, and the two were presumably bound together by the Library at some later juncture.

Dr James Freeman
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: Paper, of different stocks in each part

foliation.note: Numbered in pencil, in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, by a hand of the 20th century. The hand has numbered the parts of the manuscript separately rather than in one continuous sequence. For the purposes of cataloguing, digitisation and display, an additional prefatory number is added to each of these sequences, in order to signify the relevant part of the manuscript. So: [i] + 1:1-32 | 2:1-36 | 2:37-39 + [ii].

collation.p: The manuscript comprises two parts, both written on paper but of different stocks. The first part comprises two quires, originally of 18 leaves each. The first leaf of Quire 1 was perhaps a former pastedown, which has been excised when the manuscript was rebound. A stub before the beginning of Quire 2, and the absence of any interruption to the text, suggests that the 1st leaf was cancelled. The 2nd leaf, now f. 18, has no conjoint leaf. The 17th and 18th leaves of Quire 2, to which the 1st and 2nd leaves would have originally been attached, are no longer present. It is possible, however, that these are in fact ff. 2:37-38, which appear to be from the same paper stock and bear notes by the same hand that was responsible for copying the text in the first part of the manuscript. (This hand is nowhere to be found in the second part of the manuscript, which points to the two parts - their shared subject-matter notwithstanding - having been produced entirely separately and only bound together at a later juncture). The damage that these leaves have suffered, however, is of the same pattern as those towards the end of the second part of the manuscript, suggesting that they have been bound in this location for a lengthy period of time. The status of f. 39 is less clear, however. It too is of the same paper stock, so originally belonged with the leaves of the first part of the manuscript, but is more likely a remnant of an endleaf, pastedown or wrapper than part of either Quires 1 or 2.

The second part of the manuscript comprises two quires of 16 leaves, plus a third quire of 4 leaves: these may be two bifolia, however the tightness of the binding means that the sewing is not visible and so the structure remains uncertain.

list.item: Quire 218-3 (ff. 1:18-1:32: 1st leaf cancelled; 17th and 18th leaves not present, but probably ff. 2:37-38) |

collation.formula: 118-1 (1st excised) 218-3 (1st cancelled; 17th-18th not present, probably ff. 2:37-38) | 3-416 5four

note.p: Note concerning the rebinding of the manuscript in 1974 added to the rear pastedown by Arthur OwenOwen, A. E. B. (Arthur Ernest Bion).

binding.p: Quarter-bound binding in modern leather with marbled paper, vellum tips, by Douglas Cockerell and SonDouglas Cockerell and Son (Firm), 1974.

In an unpublished description of the manuscript by M.R. James (see Source), the manuscript is described as being bound in 'paper boards'. MS Ii.6.33 was bound with MS Ii.6.34 in this form since at least the publication of the relevant volume of the Catalogue of manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge (vol. 3, 1858), where this is noted.

In the first listing of the contents of John Moore's library in 1697 (see Provenance), these two manuscripts were described separately: Ii.6.33 as no. 253 and Ii.6.34 as no. 200. This indicates that they were at that stage physically separate items. It may be that they were bound together only after the arrival of Moore's library at Cambridge University Library in 1715, only to be separated again in 1974.

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 253 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697). This number cannot be found in the manuscript, but the description in Bernard matches the contents and it may be that the number was lost when the first leaf was excised and the manuscript rebound and/or bound with MS Ii.6.34.

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 . The donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736, usually to be found in manuscripts that came from Moore's library via the royal gift, is not present in this manuscript.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on unpublished descriptions of the manuscript and MS Ii.6.34 composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.6.33, ff. 1:1-32, 2:37-39

msItem.title: The Boke of Rota
msItem.rubric: 1:1r This boke mad a woman named Rota of the prive sicknesses that long to a woman, with medicynes to helpe them in ther neade.

msItem.title: Text
msItem.rubric: 1:1v Of sleppyng out of the matrice
msItem.incipit: 1:1v Sleppynge downe of the matrice, is when it falleth over lowe downe to the opennenge
msItem.explicit: 1:1v-1:22r potycarys haue all wey such oyles redy

list.item: Quire 218-3 (ff. 1:18-1:32: 1st leaf cancelled; 17th and 18th leaves not present, but probably ff. 2:37-38)

supportDesc.condition: Some staining around the edges of the leaves and occasionally on the text block itself. Edges of the leaves are roughly trimmed and uneven. The outer leaves (ff. 1:1r and 1:32v) are slightly grimier than the rest, presumably as a consequence of being exposed before it was bound with the rest. Folios 2:37-2:38 are in poor condition, the outer corners having in large part crumbled away; they have since been repaired.

layout.seg: Unruled, written in a single column. 16-22 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand in an inexpert, uneven secretary script.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.6.33, ff. 2:1-2:36

msItem.title: The Knowing of Woman’s kind in Childing
msItem.incipit: 2:1r Owre lord god. whan he had storid the word of all creatures.
msItem.explicit: 2:36r and than a man shaldo cure hem be no cuttynge nor be no fire.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in ornamental scrolls, drawn in ink.

supportDesc.condition: Outer leaf (folio 2:1r) is noticeably grimier than the rest, presumably as a consequence of being exposed before it was bound with the rest. Edges of the leaves are roughly trimmed. The outer corners of the leaves towards the end of the part have often crumbled away; they have since been repaired.

layout.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame only. Written in a single column, 21-22 lines to the page, below top line.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand in bastard secretary.

decoNote.p: Four-line initial in red, with infill and marginal flourishing drawn in brown ink (f. 2:1r).
Two-line initial in blue, with flourishing drawn in red ink (f. 2:17r).
Simple line-fillers drawn neatly in red ink.

note.p: Marginal annotations by one or hands of the 15th century (ff. 2:4v, 2:5v, 2:6v, 2:7r, 2:8v, 2:30r, 2:34r.
Nota marks added at intervals to the margin by the text scribe.
